sections.heading: 1.2 Applications and Challenges of Voting Theory Relevant
sections.text: In fact, voting is often used when each system with multiple autonomous agents wants to make a common decision. Common and classic applications of voting in multi-agent systems in particular and in artificial intelligence in general include collaborative filtering and recommendation systems [PHG00], planning among multiple automated agents [ER93], metasearch engines [DKNS01], spam detection [CSS99], computer-aided biology [JSA08], winning in sports competitions [BBN14], similarity search and classification of high-dimensional data [FKS03], the extensive use of voting by computer-aided agents makes the study of computer-aided aspects of voting extremely important. In many applications of voting in artificial intelligence, one often has a huge number of voters and candidates. For example, voting was used in the design of metasearch machines when the number of voting agents is not hundreds of percent.

sections.heading: 4.1.1 Related Work
sections.text: Conitzer and Sandholm show that determining whether we have enough information at any point in the selection process to find a winner under some common voting rules is mathematically insoluble [CS02]. They also demonstrate in their classic essay [CS05] that even with many commonly used voting rules that match the trivial O (mn logm) upper limit (based on sorting) for selecting preferences in an unrestricted domain, queries would have to be made. A natural question at this point is whether these limited domains also allow better selection algorithms. The answer to this is yes, and one can actually elicit the preferences from voters by using only O (mn) many queries for the domain of individual preference profiles [Con09]. Our work is part of this kind of research - we examine the number of queries that need to be asked for preference in individual crossovers.

sections.heading: 4.1.4 Our Contribution
sections.text: In this paper, we present novel algorithms for determining preferences for the range of individual crossing profiles in different constellations. We look at two different situations: when a sequence of voters is known, in respect of which the profile represents a single crossing, and when it is unknown. We also look at different access models: when the votes can be retrieved randomly, and not when they come in a predefined order. In the sequential access model, we distinguish two cases when the order of preference determination is known: the first is that the order 53 in which the votes appear is also a unique crossing order, as opposed to the time when they are not. We also demonstrate lower limits in terms of the query complexity of preference determination for the range of individual crossing profiles; these limits correspond to the upper limits up to constant factors (for a large number of voters) for all six of the above scenarios, except the case when we know a single crossing order of voters and we have access to a single row of randomly selected voters in a single case; and we have access to a single row of 6.4 voters in a single case; and we have access to the upper number of voters in a single case; and to a single number of the lower number of voters in a single result.

sections.heading: 4.2.1 Model of Input
sections.text: We examine two models of input for PREPARATION ELIZITATIONS for individual cross-sectional profiles. Random Access to Voters: In this model, we have a set of voters and may ask each voter to compare any two candidates at any time. In addition, we are also allowed to leave the input to different voters. Random Access to Voters is the input model for elections within an organization in which each voter belongs to the organization and can be queried at any time. Sequential Access to Voters: In this model, voters enter the system one by one. Once a voter has arrived, we can query voters as many times as we want, and then "free" the voter from the system to reach the next voter in the queue. Once the voter is released, he can never be queried again. Sequential55Access to Voters is actually the model of input in many practical election scenarios such as political elections, restaurant ranking, etc.

(ε, δ) -WINNER DETERMINATION) Given an r-election E whose margin of victory is at least εn, we determine the winner of the election with a probability of at least 1 − δ. (The probability is taken via the internal coin of the algorithm.) 74 We remind the reader that there are no assumptions about the distribution of votes in this problem. sections.heading: 5.1.2 Related Work
sections.text: The subject of the vote is at the core of (computational) social election theory, which is ultimately used to select multiple winners, and there is an enormous amount of literature in this area. Elections take place not only in human societies, but also in man-made social networks [BBCV09, RSW + 07] and, in general, in many multi-agent systems [ER91, PHG00]. The problem of determining the winner is the task of finding the winner in an election, given the voting rule in use and the amount of all votes cast to determine the winners. It is known that there are natural voting rules, e.g. Kemeny's reign and Dodgson's method, for which determining the winner is difficult [BITT89, HSV05, HHR97].The basic electoral model has been generalized in several other areas to capture real world situations. An important consideration is that the votes may be incomplete rankings of candidates and not a complete ranking of candidates.

sections.heading: 5.3.2 Results on Upper Bounds
sections.text: A natural way to efficiently estimate the margin of victory of an election is to calculate the margin of victory of a correspondingly small number of votes selected. Certainly, it is not immediately possible for the randomly selected samples to obtain the value of the margin of victory of the original election within a desired factor. Although it may be possible to formulate clever sampling strategies based on the margin of victory of the election, we will show that consistently selected samples are good enough to design profit margin estimation algorithms for many common voting rules. Our proposal has the advantage that the sampling component of our algorithms is always easy to implement, and beyond that there is no compromise on the limits in the sense that they are optimal for a constant number of candidates. Our algorithms include calculating a quantity (depending on the voting rule to be taken into account) based on the votes selected, which we consider to be an appropriate estimate of the margin of victory of the original election.

sections.heading: 5.4 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have introduced the (c, ε, δ) -WINNER DETERMINATION problem and (often narrow) limits on the sample complexity of many common voting rules. We have also introduced the (c, ε, δ) -MARGIN OF VICTORY problem and presented efficient voting techniques to solve it for many commonly used voting rules, which also often observe an optimal number of voting results. We observe that predicting the winner of an election requires the least number of queries, while more participating voting rules such as Borda and Maximin require significantly more voting results. In the next chapter, we examine the problem of finding a winner of an election when voting results arrive one by one in a sequential manner. 107Chapter 6Streaming algorithms for Winner DeterminationWe give the first optimal limits for returning the 1-heavy voting results in a data stream of ads, along with their endangered frequencies.

sections.heading: 7.1 Introduction
sections.text: Usually, in a voting setting, it is assumed that the votes are complete orders about the candidates. However, for many reasons, for example, lack of voter knowledge about some candidates, a voter may be indifferent between some pairs of candidates. Therefore, it is both natural and important to consider scenarios in which votes are partial orders about the candidates. If votes are only partial orders about the candidates, the winner cannot be determined with certainty, since it depends on how these partial orders are extended to linear orders. This leads to a natural arithmetic problem called POSSIBLE WINNER [KL05] Problem: Given a set of partial orders P and an excellent candidate c, there is a way to extend the partial votes to linear in order to win c. The POSSIBLE problem has been extensively studied in the literature [LPR + 07, PRVW07, Wal07, XC11, BHN09, BD09, CLMMM10, BBN11, BRR12, SFRFRn14].

sections.heading: 9.1 Introduction
sections.text: The GibbardSatterthwaite Theorem [Gib73, Sat75] proves that manipulation is inevitable in any unanimous and non-dictatorial electoral rule when we have at least three candidates. An electoral rule is called unanimously whenever a candidate is most favored by all voters, such a candidate is the winner. An electoral rule is called non-dictatorial when there is no voter whose preferred candidate is always the winner, regardless of the votes of other voters. The problem of manipulation is particularly relevant to multi-agent systems as agents have the computational power to determine strategic votes. sections.text: Researchers in the computational method of social election theory have suggested invoking the arithmetic recalcitrance of manipulation as a possible working basis for the G-S theorem. Bartholdi et al. [BO91, BTT89] first proposed the idea of using arithmetic harshness as a barrier against manipulation. Bartholdi et al. defined and studied the arithmetic problem as manipulation in which a number of manipulators have to calculate their votes to let their preferred candidate win the election. sections.heading: 9.2.1 Discussion
sections.text: The CPMW problem may be very similar to the tampering problem [BTT89, CSL07] - in both problems, a number of voters try to make a candidate the winner. However, in the CPMW problem, the actual winner must be less preferred to the current winner every time the manipulator votes. Although it may look like a subtle difference, it completely changes the nature and complexity of the problem. For example, we show that all four problems have an efficient algorithm for a large class of election rules that includes the Borda voting rule for any coalition size. However, the tampering problem for the Borda voting rule NP is complete even if we have at least two manipulators [DKNW11, BNW11]. Another important difference is that the tampering problem, unlike the problems examined in this paper, does not concern the preferences of the manipulators. We believe that there is no formal reduction between the CPMW problem and the tampering problem.

sections.heading: 10.1 Introduction
sections.text: Activities that attempt to influence the opinion of voters, in favor of particular candidates, are very common during the time that an election is in progress 09. For example, in a political election, candidates often conduct elaborate campaigns to promote themselves among a general or targeted audience. Similarly, it is not uncommon for people to protest against a national committee or court that is in the process of approving a particular policy. An extreme illustration of this phenomenon is bribery - here, candidates can create financial incentives to influence voters. Of course, the process of influencing voters can come with costs even without the aspect of bribery; for example, a typical political campaign or rally involves considerable expenditures. Any situations in which a systematic attempt is made to influence voters usually have the following aspects: an external agent that the candidate would like to be the winner, a cost model for changing the vote, a cost model for changing the vote, and knowledge of the existing election.

sections.heading: 10.5 Conclusion
sections.text: We have proposed and examined two important special cases of the $BRIBERY problem, in which the bribe is economical. Our results show that even in these special cases, the bribery problem remains persistent, subsuming such well-known hardship results in the literature. Our results confirm that bribery is a fairly hard arithmetic problem, due to the hardness of several important special cases. sections.heading: 11.1.2 Part II: Winner Determination
sections.text: Chapter 5: Win Prediction and Margin in Estimating Victory We presented efficient algorithms for predicting the winner of an election and estimating the profit margin of an election. We also showed interesting lower boundaries for the sampling complexity of these problems, which show that our algorithms are often optimal up to constant factors. Chapter 6: Streaming Algorithms for Determining the Winner In this work, we investigated the spatial complexity of determining approximate winners in the environment in which votes are continuously inserted into a data stream. We showed that enabling randomization and approximation actually allows for much more space-saving algorithms. In addition, our boundaries are narrow in certain parameter areas.

sections.heading: 11.1.3 Part III: Election Control
sections.text: Chapter 7: Kerelization for Possible Winners and Coalition Manipulation In this work, we have demonstrated that the possible winner problem does not allow for efficient pre-processing rules, formally no kerelization algorithms for many common voting rules, including valuation rules, maximin, Copeland, rank pairs, and Bucklin, when parameterized by the number of candidates. Chapter 8: Manipulation with Partial VotesIn this chapter, we have followed a comprehensive study of manipulation with incomplete votes. We have proposed three natural extensions of manipulation in the usual complete information geared to the incomplete information environment, namely weak manipulation, opportunistic manipulation, and strong manipulation. We have solved the computational complexity of all three problems for many common voting rules, including plurality.

sections.heading: 11.2 Future Directions of Research
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

metadata.abstractText: In many real world situations, especially involving multiagent systems and artificial intelligence, participating agents often need to agree upon a common alternative even if they have differing preferences over the available alternatives. Voting is one of the tools of choice in these situations. Common and classic applications of voting in modern applications include collaborative filtering and recommender systems, metasearch engines, coordination and planning among multiple automated agents etc. Agents in these applications usually have computational power at their disposal. This makes the study of computational aspects of voting crucial. This thesis is devoted to a study of computational complexity of several fundamental algorithmic and complexity-theoretic problems arising in the context of voting theory. The typical setting for our work is an “election”; an election consists of a set of voters or agents, a set of alternatives, and a voting rule. The vote of any agent can be thought of as a ranking (more precisely, a complete order) of the set of alternatives. A voting profile comprises a collection of votes of all the agents. Finally, a voting rule is a mapping that takes as input a voting profile and outputs an alternative, which is called the “winner” or “outcome” of the election. Our contributions in this thesis can be categorized into three parts and are described below. Part I: Preference Elicitation. In the first part of the thesis, we study the problem of eliciting the preferences of a set of voters by asking a small number of comparison queries (such as who a voter prefers between two given alternatives) for various interesting domains of preferences. We commence with considering the domain of single peaked preferences on trees in Chapter 3.
